job_title: Director in Buies Creek, NC
pros: The best part of working for CU is the people. For the most part, the people you work with on a daily basis are awesome. My CU team became like a family, and even after leaving the university for a new position, I still was in contact with my "CU Crowd."
cons: The DRAMA...there was always departmental drama everywhere. Each department worked within a silo and working together was often challenging. My least favorite thing about Campbell wasn't even the lack of diversity or women in leadership, it was the "this is how we do it at Campbell" excuse for literally everything. Growth often requires change. This university doesn't like change. Thus, growth is hard to come by. There is a very strong "good ol' boys" club mentality here. There are some women in leadership, but I question how much they are able to actually "lead" with the current infrastructure. There is also a very noticeable lack of diversity within the core leadership group. Lastly, the pay is pennies. It's well below average especially since you are often asked to do the job that three or four people do at other universities.

review_title: Working at Campbell University is like a trip back in time to the 19th century.
job_title: Receptionist in Buies Creek, NC
pros: You will have a job? (Note: Glassdoor requires a five-word minimum to contribute a review.)
cons:
Everything. 

Campbell University hides behind a religious affiliation with meager academic contributions from faculty. Even a small child can see through this institution’s branded tomfoolery. 

As an employee, you’ll be solicited to contribute your (unlivable) wages back to the university as a donor. If you go above the basic requirements of your job, you’ll be punished with more work and expected to maintain optimum performance without a pay raise - year, after year, after year, after year.

Reduction in benefits are sold as a system-wide effort to maintain operations, and employees are conditioned to believe they should be “grateful” to have a job. 

My advice to employees with familial ties to Harnett County - get out! Stakeholders are brainwashed to believe the university contributes back to rural communities, but fails to provide a living wage to any front-line workers, many who live in the same community where the university resides. 

Your contributions will never be appreciated and your presence, should you decide to leave, will not be missed. With a never-ending supply of recent college graduates, the university has no need to retain good workers.

review_title: Great place to work in a close knit community. Can be hard to make your way ahead here if you are not liked.
job_title: Adjunct in Buies Creek, NC
pros: Campbell University is always growing always changing and especially with the opening of a new med school, pt school and nursing school so its great to get it on the ground floor. Small campus where everybody knows your name much like an episode of Cheers.  Faculty member care about the students and each other and its a very warm environment.
cons: Can be hard to get ahead if you don't know somebody who knows somebody. It's important to not step on anyone's toes in such a small community lest something you did on a Friday night prevent you getting a job on Monday morning. Pay isn't as competitive as a large research university would be for someone with a terminal degree.

review_title: Friendly and comfortable work environment.  A great place to work.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Raleigh, NC
pros: Faculty and staff are friendly and open to questions.  Very easy to fit in.  They are very flexible toward work-life balance issues and maintain enthusiasm for their mission.  Staff works closely with the students, so strong interpersonal skills a must.  The law professors are some of the best in town, and bring their expertise and passion inside and outside the classroom.
cons: Could do more to foster professional development.  There is little opportunity for advancement within the school, so people who want to move along their career path may have to leave in order to find more opportunities.

job_title: Adjunct Instructor in Buies Creek, NC
pros: Other faculty members genuinely care about and engage with students.  The university also regularly reinvests in campus infrastructure and into growing flagship programs.
cons: IT infrastructure is lagging - but also actively under renovation.  Academic programs that are not high-profile seem to lag visibly behind other departments in facility quality and budget.

review_title: Small Town Feel at Division I School
job_title: Athletics in Buies Creek, NC
pros: The people that work at the school are excellent and some of the best that I have been around. Everyone is also very friendly and tries to be helpful. The facilities have been undergoing a major upgrade over the last five years.
cons: It is located in a very small town without access to stores, restaurants or much nearby culture. It is just the way the school is set up.

job_title: Assistant Professor in Buies Creek, NC
pros: Some professors really care about their students and have great energy. Certain people in the administration are AWESOME! The new president could potentially bring great change. It's a beautiful campus. And our new president seems very serious about listening to students and putting their needs first.
cons: Some professors and department heads have very dismissive attitudes toward students and seem to be teaching because they get a thrill out of belittling young adults. Upper management puts too much trust in the middle management. Some middle managers are lying about how well things are going in their department. Mine is barely hanging on. The campus feels like it is in the middle of nowhere and students who stay on campus all week--mostly done by those who do not have cars--frequently experience bouts of depression around the start of Spring semester. The university claims financial health, but I think it acquires financial health, at least in part, by being cheap with its professors. My initial hiring salary was on the bottom of the large range of salaries acceptable for a beginning assistant professor, but I was promised I would quickly make up ground with significant annual raises. Once I started, I learned that the annual raises would not be significant. Our employee insurance plan is worse than the one I had as part-time employee graduate student. When I interviewed, I was also told that my department wanted my ideas on how they could grow into a larger department and maybe even a powerhouse within the state. Once hired, it slowly became clear that no one wanted to hear my thoughts about the program. I was just meant to stand in line and become a soldier for the ideas the chair of the department already had in motion.

review_title: Always beware no matter how many good things you are doing.
job_title: Manager in Buies Creek, NC
pros: There are none to list. The blind seem to be leading the blind. There is no continuity within the management ranks. Everyone with a position has an agenda.

job_title: Teaching Assistant in Buies Creek, NC
pros:

•	Guided students in conducting lab and interpreting the data from lab experiments using graphs and JMP 
•	Taught basic laboratory technology and safety techniques along with concepts such as cell division, DNA fragmentation, UV spectrophotometer and Gel Electrophoresis
cons: It is not easy to manage over 15 students in a lab.
